gov.nasa.larcfm.Util

Class WGS84

  • java.lang.Object
    • gov.nasa.larcfm.Util.WGS84

  • public final class WGS84
extends java.lang.Object
    This class contains values and formulas used for a WGS-84 reference ellipsoid.

    This is based on "Department of Defense World Geodetic System 1984", NIMA TR8350.2, Third Edition, 4 July 1997.

    Notes:

    • The Earth does not rotate. This may change.
    • Positive latitude is north and positive longitude is east.

    • Field Summary

      static double omega
      Angular velocity of the Earth

      This method performs a particular projection from a WGS-84 reference elipsoid Earth latitude/longitude coordinate system to Euclidean (XY) one.

    • Field Detail

      • flattening

        public static final double flattening
        WGS-84 earth flattening parameter. minor = major*(1 - flattening)
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • major

        public static final double major
        The semi-major axis from the WGS 84 reference ellipsoid. This corresponds to the equatorial radius, +/- 2 meters.

      • minor

        public static final double minor
        Computation of the WGS 84 semi-minor axis: major*(1 - flattening)

      • omega

        public static final double omega
        Angular velocity of the Earth

      • GM

        public static final double GM
        Earth's gravitational constant, including atmosphere

      • Me

        public static final double Me
        Earth's mass

    • Method Detail

      • gravity

        public static double gravity(double lat)
        gravitational acceleration at the surface as a function of latitude, page 4-1.

      • gravity

        public static double gravity(double lat,
                             double height)
        gravitational acceleration as a function of latitude and height above the ellipsoid, page 4-1. This equation should be valid for aircraft heights, orbital mechanics may need a better estimate.

      • gravity_alt

        public static double gravity_alt(double height)
        gravitational acceleration as a function of the height above the ellipsoid at 45 degrees latitude. This equation should be valid for aircraft heights, orbital mechanics may need a better estimate.

      • project_xy

        public static Vect2 project_xy(double lat0,
                               double lon0,
                               double lat1,
                               double lon1)
        This method performs a particular projection from a WGS-84 reference elipsoid Earth latitude/longitude coordinate system to Euclidean (XY) one. Lat/long #0 are placed at the origin of the XY coordinate system. The returned value is an XY position of point #1 relative to point #0. This projection is based on the Aviation Formulary by Ed Williams v1.44

        Note: this projection does not have a symmetric correspondence, that is, project_xy(lat0,lon0,lat1,lon1) /= -project_xy(lat1,lon1,lat0,lon0)
